Structure. Vertex with big and flattened anteorbital tubercles. Genal processes 0.8–1.1 times as long as vertex along midline, adpressed medially ( Fig. 73 ). Antenna 4.1–4.4 times as long as head width. Forewing ( Fig. 75 ) 2.5–2.7 times as long as head width, 2.1–2.2 times as long as wide; pterostigma moderately short, narrow at base; cell cu 1 0.8 times higher than wide; surface spinules much reduced, present only in apical half of cell r 1 , and around the radular areas in the middle of cells r 2 , m 1 , m 2 and cu 1 , and in cell cu 2 leaving broad spinule-free stripes along the veins. Metatibia 0.6 times as long as head width. Terminalia as in Figs 83, 94, 95 , 100, 101 . Male proctiger 0.4 times as head width, lacking posterior lobes basally but weakly produced, evenly rounded. Paramere lamellar, irregularly tapering to apex; with one slightly forward directed sclerotised tooth near apex in the middle; inner surface sparsely covered in long setae, denser and thicker apically, covering more or less apical third. Distal segment of aedeagus strongly inflated in apical third, bearing a sclerotised bar in the middle on either side, base with large projection; sclerotised end tube of ductus ejaculatorius large, slightly curved, originating in apical half of segment. Female proctiger 1.0–1.1 times as long as head width, dorsal outline almost straight, apex slightly upturned, pointed; circumanal ring 0.3 times as long as proctiger. Female subgenital plate 0.4–0.5 times as long as proctiger, apex subacute; dorsal outline with distinct angular lobe in apical third.

Measurements (in mm) and ratios ( 4 ♂ , 3 ♀ ). Head width ♂ 0.92–0.98, ♀ 1.00–1.04; antenna length ♂ 3.80–4.04, ♀ 4.20–4.60; forewing length ♂ 2.38–2.58, ♀ 2.58–2.76; male proctiger length 0.34–0.38; paramere length 0.28–0.30; length of distal segment of aedeagus 0.30–0.32; female proctiger length 1.24–1.48.
Fifth instar immature ( Fig. 77 ). Colouration. Dirty whitish, antenna yellowish with apices of flagellar segments brown. Tibiae and tarsi greyish brown. Abdomen whitish.

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. Adjective, feminine form. From Latin uncus = hook, barb, clamp, and -ger = bearing, for the con- spicuous hook on the aedeagus.

J. basifistula

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution . Brazil ( MG , MS , PR , SP).

Host plant, biology and habitat .
Copaifera langsdorffii Desf.
—Two specimens ( 1 ♂ , 1 ♀ ) were parasitised by Strepsiptera ( Fig. 222 ).—Cerrado, transition between Atlantic forest and cerrado, riparian forest, degraded forests, forest edges, isolated trees, plantations, parks.

Comments .
Jataiba uncigera
differs from other copaiba psyllids as indicated in the key.
Jataiba uncigera
shares with
J. basifistula
,
J. cearensis
,
J. cognata
and
J. incisa
the long, evenly tapering and pointed genal processes, the very long antennae, and the broad forewing with a short and basally narrow pterostigma, suggesting the five species may constitute a monophyletic group. Within this group
J. uncigera
is morphologically most similar to
J. cearensis
, from which it differs in the slightly larger body dimensions and, most importantly, in the posterior margin of the male proctiger which is evenly rounded in basal third (rather than angular), in the paramere where the densely spaced spines in the apical third of the inner face cover a larger area, and in the distal aedeagal segment where the basal projection is larger. We could not find any differences between the females of the two species.
